channel.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
channel.description:
I'll give you the basics of it:
We were supposed to download a jar file, add it to out project as an external jar - easy enough -The jar has 4 .class files which all have a constructor and various methods
Each class file is a various "collection" meaning one is cards, one is music, one is spoons from landmarks, and the last is video games.
Our job is to create a basic program that can serve as a collection for all the class files. Our teacher told us he also may be adding other .class files in the jar at a later time. The point of that being that our program should be able to take new forms of collections with various edits.
This is probably the most difficult program we have had to do and I'm lost atm. I'm sure most of you guys are like ffs marcbob wtf it's easy you idiot
I don't even get the point of the jar file. I have never done anything with one before. How am I supposed to use the constructors and methods in it? Also, what would be the best way to approach this project? -If you're really up for helping me on this I could send you word for word the entire project assignment and the jar file. I may pay you a few bucks for helping, but I want to do most of this myself so I learn

item.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

daemon504:

marcbob im your biggest fan!, im a newish java coder ive started a server using google 637 it helped me learn to code alot better, i also dont understand jar files… what happened to project marcbob?

That server was only good for it’s time. I drained like $100 into running Arrav after it shutdown and then the original Owner found out and made me shut down. Haven’t ran a server since that because I don’t feel like using start up money or working on a server.

@TOPIC: This topic is old but I figured it out and if anyone wants the code I can send you it. It was actually not that hard to do once I figured out what to do.

Read full topic
item.source: Need some help getting started with a school assignment

item.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

daemon504:

marcbob im your biggest fan!, im a newish java coder ive started a server using google 637 it helped me learn to code alot better, i also dont understand jar files… what happened to project marcbob?

:fp:

BaseballCards[] collection;
?
Object[] generalCollection;
^ no idea if that works lol

ArrayList<Object> gcol = new ArrayList<Object>(); gcol.add(new Color(0)); gcol.add(new JFrame("Heya!")); gcol.add("MIKU HATSUNE IS AWESOME!");
That’s probably the best you can do.
EDIT: see if they all extend the same class (which is why Object works always)
The reason why Object works on all those different objects is because every object in Java is a direct or indirect extension of java.lang.Object.

Read full topic

item.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

imthenull:

Too lazy to actually help you out. I’m thinking he wants to you implement your own Collection?

No lol. I can see where you think that, but he literally wants us to implement a collection meaning baseball cards and that sort of thing. Literally things a person collects and then we need to maintain them.

I’m trying to do this with an ArrayList of types of the jar, but I am getting a runtime error when trying to make a constructor from a class in the jar file. I’ll figure it out hopefully.

Read full topic

item.source: Need some help getting started with a school assignment

item.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:4, topic:509488”][quote author=Arcik link=topic=627733.msg4266089#msg4266089 date=1364070227]
There are several reasons we have a jar file for example applications, organisation etc etc.
[/quote]
Your post was very misleading.

There are several components to a jar, a few including:

[ul][li]Smaller (disk space wise) than a group of classes (a jar is just a zip archive)[/li]
[li]You can optionally include a manifest into the archive, which allows for easy execution[/li]
[li]Ability to load a magnitude of classes into the JVM with ease. “java -jar foo.jar” ‘foo.jar’ may contain as many classes as you’d like.[/li]
[li]Finally, as Arcik stated, organization. Mainly when working with external libraries[/li][/ul]

Once you import a jar you would already have access to the methods etc inside it, but if you don’t know what those class’s called or what methods are within them i’d suggest decompiling it since there are only 4 class’s.

First of all, you don’t import a jar, you include them into your class path. Secondly, if you’re using a 3rd party jar and don’t know what it contains then you have issues, there are Javadocs for a reason.[/quote]

Import is more of a child word for the whole input concept; I doubt his teacher made any sort of docs for his jar which is why I said to decompile.

Read full topic

I don’t understand how I should keep track of all these “collectibles.” If anyone seriously wants to help me, I can send you the assignment and the jar. Or you can just teamview me and we can discuss the topic and stuff[/quote]
Have you included the jar into your classpath?

item.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

Arcik:

There are several reasons we have a jar file for example applications, organisation etc etc.

Your post was very misleading.

There are several components to a jar, a few including:

[ul][li]Smaller (disk space wise) than a group of classes (a jar is just a zip archive)[/li]
[li]You can optionally include a manifest into the archive, which allows for easy execution[/li]
[li]Ability to load a magnitude of classes into the JVM with ease. “java -jar foo.jar” ‘foo.jar’ may contain as many classes as you’d like.[/li]
[li]Finally, as Arcik stated, organization. Mainly when working with external libraries[/li][/ul]

Arcik:

Once you import a jar you would already have access to the methods etc inside it, but if you don’t know what those class’s called or what methods are within them i’d suggest decompiling it since there are only 4 class’s.

First of all, you don’t import a jar, you include them into your class path. Secondly, if you’re using a 3rd party jar and don’t know what it contains then you have issues, there are Javadocs for a reason.

Read full topic
item.source: Need some help getting started with a school assignment

item.title: Need some help getting started with a school assignment
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

Arcik:

[quote=marcbob]I don’t even get the point of the jar file

There are several reasons we have a jar file for example applications, organisation etc etc.

Once you import a jar you would already have access to the methods etc inside it, but if you don’t know what those class’s called or what methods are within them i’d suggest decompiling it since there are only 4 class’s.[/quote]

No I have the jar imported fine and everything and can see all it’s methods. I understand now I can extend the class files in the jar and have access to their methods.

The issue I’m having is finding a way to keep track of all the “collections” like it is asking. Should I use an Array or an ArrayList and how should I go about doing it?

The 4 kinds of collections are souvenir spoons, old video games, music, and baseball cards. I need to make a program that can easily take input of more collections and manage them all so you can remove one from a list. Then I need to be able to show the oldest and newest item, cheapest, most valuable. Then i need to be able to get a total and average value of the collection.

So I’m just failing to see how I should take the user input in the constructor of like one kind of collection and do it similarly for the other. They all are done differently.

Read full topic
